And even in a scenario with a valuation reset (a 28.8x weighted average Price/Earnings ratio of the S&P 500 index does look quite elevated), as we can deduce from PVAL's past performance (cautiously, of course, as past returns guarantee nothing in the future), it should do much better than the market (an around 84% downside capture ratio is what I am referring to).

So now, let us delve into all the details and discuss what is so special about PVAL.

Basics of The Putnam Focused Large Cap Value ETF

  • Inception: May 25, 2021
  • Investment Manager: Putnam Investment Management, LLC
  • Total Net Assets: $4.95 billion, as of October 30
  • Net Expense Ratio: 0.56%
  • 3-Year Annualized Return (October 2022–September 2025): 23.04% vs. 24.9% of the iShares Core S&P 500 ETF (IVV) and 16.71% of the iShares Russell 1000 Value ETF (IWD)

PVAL Strategy

As we know from the Franklin Templeton website, incepted in May 2021, PVAL is managed actively, seeking "capital growth and current income."

As explained on page 2 of the summary prospectus, PVAL

...invests mainly in common stocks of U.S. companies, with a focus on value stocks that offer the potential for capital growth, current income, or both.

From the exact same page, we know that large-cap companies are defined as those "...of a size similar to those in the Russell 1000 Value Index." And this index is PVAL's benchmark, as per the factsheet. However, it is also added that the ETF can venture into the mid-size universe as well.

As to the valuation characteristics, Putnam Investment Management, LLC, the ETF's investment manager, decides whether a company is "...currently undervalued by the market" or not.

PVAL Is An Active Nontransparent ETF

When assessing PVAL, investors should pay close attention to the fact that this vehicle is nontransparent. In practice, this means that the ETF publishes its detailed portfolio monthly and not daily.

As of writing this article, the most recent portfolio available on the PVAL website was as of September 30, 2025. And even though the tracking basket is released on each business day, I should remind you that securities inside it are not what the fund actually holds (there should be an overlap though).

So being an ANT ETF has essentially two sides.

  • On the one hand, it is quite beneficial, as traders who have strategies based on copying funds' most promising ideas (the result can be these funds' top ideas failing, which is not pleasant) have close to zero chances here (alas, not zero).
  • On the other hand, a few quite sensitive issues arise.

For instance, as explained by PVAL:

You may have to pay more money to trade the ETF's shares. This ETF will provide less information to traders, who tend to charge more for trades when they have less information.

More details on risks and disadvantages can be found in the prospectus.

Obviously, as I have already explained in the article on the T. Rowe Price Dividend Growth ETF (TDVG), the ANT approach creates understandable challenges for ETF researchers, as they simply have no up-to-date holdings to analyze and thus have to make certain compromises.

The solution I use in my articles on the ANT vehicles is that I take the most recent financial metrics (today, the data I am using is as of October 31) and pair them with the most recent portfolio available. Thus, we can get a general understanding of an ETF's factor mix, but of course it is far from perfect. This is what we will be doing today.

PVAL Portfolio Analysis

As of September 30, PVAL had a portfolio of 46 holdings, 45 of them being equities and one being quite a significant cash position with a 2.62% weight. Citigroup Inc. (C) was the top name, with a 4.18% weight. Here, I should note that at least as of September, the ETF was quite bullish on the financial sector overall, with a 20.13% allocation, which makes it more of a contrarian play compared to IVV, which is enamored of IT.

  • Compared to IWD, the ETF that tracks its benchmark, PVAL is underweight in six sectors, the key two among them being communication and real estate. It is overweight in five sectors, especially in consumer staples, which gives it a slight defensive tilt.
  • Compared to IVV (which I use as a market proxy in my articles), PVAL is substantially underweight in IT, plus it has smaller exposure to communication and consumer discretionary. The main sector it is overweight in is financials.

Top Ten Holdings

Company Weight in PVAL, as of September 30 Weight in IVV, as of October 30 Weight in IWD, as of October 30 Sector Market Cap, $ Billion
C 4.18% 0.32% 0.52% Financials 179.32
Walmart Inc. (WMT) 3.85% 0.77% 1.37% Consumer Staples 815.06
Exxon Mobil Corporation (XOM) 3.33% 0.84% 1.71% Energy 488.95
Cisco Systems, Inc. (CSCO) 3.04% 0.50% 1.00% Information Technology 287.32
Seagate Technology Holdings plc (STX) 3.03% 0.10% N/A Information Technology 57.42
Alphabet Inc. (GOOGL) (GOOG) 3.01% 5.07% 3.62% Communication 3,401.71
McKesson Corporation (MCK) 2.98% 0.18% 0.03% Health Care 102.68
Bank of America Corporation (BAC) 2.97% 0.62% 1.13% Financials 388.68
American International Group, Inc. (AIG) 2.91% 0.07% 0.15% Financials 43.32
Philip Morris International Inc. (PM) 2.85% 0.39% 0.78% Consumer Staples 226.89

Created by the author using data from the ETFs and Seeking Alpha. Market cap data as of October 31. For IVV and IWD, the weights of GOOG and GOOGL were summed up. PVAL had exposure to GOOGL only

The key ten holdings of PVAL have significantly smaller weights in the S&P 500 ETF. This is also the case with the IWD portfolio, with a nuance being that it has no exposure to STX and is overweight in Alphabet.

Besides, my analysis illustrated that nearly all PVAL's holdings are S&P 500 constituents, with just four exceptions, including AstraZeneca PLC (AZN).

Parameter Weight in PVAL (as of September 30) Weight in IVV (as of October 30)
Companies present in both PVAL and IVV 91.57% 22.14%

Calculated by the author using data from the ETFs and Seeking Alpha

Most can be found in the IWD portfolio as well.

Parameter Weight in PVAL (as of September 30) Weight in IWD (as of October 30)
Companies present in both PVAL and IWD 83.28% 19.84%

Calculated by the author using data from the ETFs and Seeking Alpha

PVAL Factor Mix

Now let us review PVAL's portfolio from a different angle—with parameters indicative of its exposure to the style factors added to gain deeper insights. Again, we are discussing the PVAL portfolio as of September 30 but with financial data as of October 31.

Below, I would like to summarize a few essential takeaways.

  • PVAL is far from being a pure value ETF (a 13.88% allocation to stocks with a B- Quant Valuation rating or higher is too small to earn that status). However, its adjusted weighted average earnings yield is the highest compared to those of IWD and IVV, while EV/EBITDA and Price/Sales are the lowest.
  • It is a bit growthier than IWD, as illustrated by the weighted average forward growth rates.
  • Nevertheless, compared to the Russell 1000 Value ETF, it has a slightly smaller exposure to stocks with a B- Quant Profitability grade or higher. At the same time, its return on total capital and return on assets are stronger.
  • IVV looks mostly stronger than PVAL, but it is also meaningfully more expensive.

What Is So Special About PVAL's Performance?

There is a lot to appreciate about PVAL's performance. Put shortly, it has outperformed IVV and IWD (the ETF that tracks its benchmark) since inception, delivered excellent results compared to the Large Value subclass, and has demonstrated fairly healthy risk characteristics. Let us address all these one by one.

PVAL Outperformance Since Inception

Since May 26, 2021, PVAL has outperformed IVV by approximately 6.17%. It has beaten IVE, IWD, and RPV with ease.

To give a bit more context on that, this year, it has been ahead of IVV for quite some time, though in October, the S&P 500 ETF was a bit racier, so it is outperforming PVAL year-to-date for now.

Annualized Returns And Risk Metrics

Over June 2021–September 2025, compared to RPV, IWD, IVE, and IVV, PVAL delivered the highest CAGR, the strongest risk-adjusted returns (the Sharpe and Sortino ratios), and the smallest downside capture ratio.

Besides, it had the strongest upside capture ratio among the value ETFs.

Next, over the March 2022–September 2025 period (shortened because of the Capital Group Dividend Value ETF (CGDV)), it has been one of the best again, as it trailed only CGDV (which also had stronger upside capture and more comfortable downside capture).

PVAL vs. Large Value ETFs

Over periods from one month to three years, PVAL did an excellent job delivering price and total returns considerably stronger than the median figures for the subclass.

Metric PVAL Median for the Large Value subclass
1M Price Return 0.89% -0.39%
6M Price Return 17.09% 12.00%
YTD Price Return 16.11% 10.01%
1Y Price Return 13.24% 7.74%
3Y Price Return 61.50% 37.42%
3Y Total Return 68.46% 45.69%

Calculated by the author using data from Seeking Alpha as of October 31

Final Thoughts

In conclusion, considering the balance of positives and negatives, I believe PVAL deserves a cautious Buy rating.

Sure, it has a few disadvantages. For instance, while its factor mix is healthy and supportive of a Buy rating, I would appreciate stronger quality. Besides, its expense ratio of 0.56% is quite high, to be honest. While this is a comparatively adequate ER for an actively managed vehicle, it is still worth remembering that the high fee is constantly detracting from the total returns.
